title: Martin Allen sacked by National League big-spenders Eastleigh after just 14 games in charge
text:
mad dog put down Martin Allen sacked by National League big-spenders Eastleigh after just 14 games in charge 
Former Notts County and Leicester boss only joined from League 2 Barnet on 1 December but won just two games By Fred Nathan Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Comments MARTIN ALLEN has been sacked by Eastleigh after just 14 games in charge of the National League side. 
The big-spending Spitfires lost 1-0 to Macclesfield last night seeing them fall to 15th place and go seven games without a league victory, nine points above the drop zone. Getty Images 5 Eastleigh boss Martin Allen has left the club after just 14 games in charge 
Keep up to date with ALL the EFL news, gossip, transfers and goals on our dedicated page plus fixtures, results and analysis 
Former Notts County and Leicester boss Allen, 51, only joined from Barnet on 1 December, opting to drop a league to take charge of the promotion favourites. 
Transfer dealings were not an issue in his brief 84-day spell on the south coast, bringing in 13 players and letting 19 players move on. News Group Newspapers Ltd 5 He only joined from Barnet in December but his time on the south coast has not been happy 
But he won just two matches out of 14 and departed, leaving the club to find it’s fourth manager of a turbulent season after Chris Todd and Ronnie Moore also left. 
Having not won a single home game, he said last night after Macclesfield won that he was “not enjoying it” at the Silverlake Stadium. News Group Newspapers Ltd 5 “Mad Dog” is known for his passionate demeanour on the touchline 
He criticised his players last night as well, saying: “I’ve stood back and watched some games here, watched our team play and it’s been awful, nowhere near good enough. related stories Sutton United star Roarie Deacon is wanted by Fulham, Charlton, Cardiff, Millwall and Nottingham Forest mowst wanted Blackburn Rovers announce Tony Mowbray as new head coach after Owen Coyle departure DWIGHTMARE Newcastle United sweating on the fitness of Dwight Gayle ahead of crunch Championship clashes TOP BILLING Huddersfield 1 Reading 0: Philip Billing's late strike fires Terriers to within four points of automatic promotion spots DREAM FADING Derby 0 Burton Albion 0: Rams' play-off hopes take huge hit as Nigel Clough secures point on return to Derby Float like a butterfly Sheffield Wednesday 1 Brentford 2: John Egan and Harlee Dean head home as Bees sting playoff-chasing rivals Con Artist QPR 2 Wigan 1: Conor Washington grabs a goal and an assist to lead Ian Holloway's side to the verge of safety PREVIEW Everton vs Sunderland: What TV channel is it on, What time is kick off and what is the latest team news? ow no Owen Coyle sacked by struggling Blackburn Rovers after less than a season in charge at Ewood Park following Cup defeat Preview Manchester United vs Southampton: When is the EFL Cup final and what TV channel is it on? “It’s not acceptable to me; it’s not acceptable to the chairman.“I’ve had two clubs win championships, with Gillingham and at Barnet, and it’s been through hard work, desire and everybody in the team competing week in, week out. Action Images 5 He has had a lot of success at Barnet, but has left them high and dry on a number of occasions 
“I’m not getting that here at the moment and I’m not enjoying it. I haven’t got the vibe. 
“I love the place, I love working with the chairman, I love the atmosphere when the crowd do get behind the players, but the players haven’t given the crowd anything to lift them.” News Group Newspapers Ltd 5 He spent most of his playing days with West Ham before becoming a manager 
Allen has a long association with Barnet, who he won the National League title with in 2015 and has managed in four separate spells. 
But he also left the Bees high and dry a number of times , moving to Brentford, Notts County, Gillingham and Eastleigh from north London. Brentford 5-1 Eastleigh : Tom Field scores twice in comfortable Bee's win 
He has also had spells in charge of MK Dons, Leicester City and Cheltenham Town, having earned his nickname "Mad Dog" for his tenacious playing career with the likes of QPR and West Ham - and his honest and passionate managerial style.
